etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Owles Almanacke. From frost + nip, after frostnip and frostnipped

definitions: Originally: †extremely cold air or wind; an instance of this (obsolete). In later use: frostbite, specifically in a less severe form affecting only the superficial layers of the skin.

etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in John Pory (bap. 1572, d. ?1636), writer and colonial administrator. From frost + nip

definitions: To injure or damage by frost or extreme cold (frequently in figurative contexts and figurative); specifically to affect with frostnip.
